Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Evolution of Warm Dense Matter at Ultrafast Time Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Warm dense matter (WDM) has been the focus of research for astrophysics, fusion physics, high-energy physics, and energy applications among others. Due to the limitation in the instrument's spatial resolution, one fundamental question remains: how will electrons behave after being ejected from a material? The recent advancements in picosecond electron schlieren radiography (PESR) is now making it possible to investigate this problem. Through collaboration with Dr. Jie Chen from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China, an expert in ultrafast dynamics, the EAPSI fellow will conduct the experiment, develop and perform the data analysis to participate in the mapping of the physical shape and time evolution of the ejected electrons. Understanding the behavior of ejected electrons is expected to contribute to advancement in fundamental knowledge in physics.

Specifically, in this project, the EAPSI fellow will explore the possibility of extending the current picosecond electron schlieren capability from the time consuming multiple-shot to the more efficient single-shot mode. This will increase the spatial resolution to a level of sensitivity capable of directly measuring the ejected charge dynamics, which can be further converted to transient electric fields by using Maxwell?s equations. These new measurement capabilities will offer insight into the physics governing the laser-induced plasma dynamics. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the summer of 2015, EAPSI provided me the opportunity to conduct scientific research under the guidance of my host advisor, Dr. Jie Chen at Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU), Shanghai. The project consisted of using picosecond electron schlieren radiography (PESR) to map the three dimensional distribution of the TEFs with two objectives in mind. The first objective was to utilize an innovative technique to directly measure the transient electric field (TEF) produced from warm dense matter (WDM) gold nanofilms. Second, the data acquired from TEFs was analyzed to extract the charge density of the WDM and compare it to a previously developed model. In addition to the objectives, we hope to further analyze the data to calculate several quantities, such as the three dimensional electric field, three dimensional charge density, and the number of charges expelled.

 

The program was divided in three phases: training, experiments and data analysis. During the first phase I was trained in PESR experimental techniques. At this time I was explained the history of PESR, the mechanism of how it works, its limitations and the challenges that needed to be overcome to make it a reliable technique. In the second phase, twelve experiments were carried out, each resulting in one hundred and twenty images. Each experiment recorded data from a small section of the WDM gold nanofilm and each image is a snapshot in time of the time evolution of the TEF. For the third phase and final phase a Matlab program was created, which is capable of tracking and recording the TEF as time evolves.

 

The preliminary results are in good agreement with the literature. Quantities, such as the speed at which the TEF travels and the number of charges expelled has been measured indirectly in the past and they agree with the results obtain with PESR.  Though agreement with previous results is important, we have new results including the three dimensional electric field and three dimensional charge density. Constant communication with Dr. Chen over the results and possible future collaborations are ongoing.

Second, the data acquired from TEFs was analyzed to extract the charge density of the WDM and compare it to a previously developed model. In addition to the objectives, we hope to further analyze the data to calculate several quantities, such as the three dimensional electric field, three dimensional charge density, and the number of charges expelled. The program was divided in three phases: training, experiments and data analysis. During the first phase I was trained in PESR experimental techniques. Though agreement with previous results is important, we have new results including the three dimensional electric field and three dimensional charge density.
